        <tr>

          <td id="LC54" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> For some data, algorithms that learn complex relationships between variables </td>

          <td id="L60" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="60"></td>
          <td id="LC60" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> The Super Learner solves this issue of algorithm selection by creating an</td>

        <tr>

</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L68" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="68"></td>

</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L69" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="69"></td>
          <td id="LC69" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In [<span class="pl-e">Chapter 1</span>](#intro), we introduced the [_Roadmap for Targeted</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L70" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="70"></td>
          <td id="LC70" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Learning_](#roadmap) as a general template to translate real-world data</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L71" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="71"></td>
          <td id="LC71" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">applications into formal statistical estimation problems. The first steps of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L72" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="72"></td>
          <td id="LC72" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this roadmap define the <span class="pl-mi">*statistical estimation problem*</span>, which establish</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L73" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="73"></td>
          <td id="LC73" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L74" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="74"></td>
          <td id="LC74" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">1.</span> <span class="pl-mb">**The data <span class="pl-cce">\$</span>O$ as a random variable, or equivalently, a realization of a**</span> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L75" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="75"></td>
          <td id="LC75" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   <span class="pl-mb">**particular experiment/study, which has probability distribution $P_0$.**</span> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L76" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="76"></td>
          <td id="LC76" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   This is written $O <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>im P_0$, and $P_0$ is also commonly referred to as the </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L77" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="77"></td>
          <td id="LC77" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   data-generating process (DGP) and also the data-generating distribution </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L78" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="78"></td>
          <td id="LC78" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   (DGD). The data structure $O$ is comprised of variables, such as a </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L79" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="79"></td>
          <td id="LC79" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   vector of covariates $W$, a treatment or exposure $A$, and an outcome $Y$, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L80" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="80"></td>
          <td id="LC80" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   $O=(W,A,Y) <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>im P_0$. We often observe the random variable $O$ $n$ times, by </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L81" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="81"></td>
          <td id="LC81" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   repeating the common experiment $n$ times. For example, $O_1,<span class="pl-cce">\l</span>dots, O_n$ </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L82" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="82"></td>
          <td id="LC82" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   random variables could be the result of a random sample of $n$ subjects from </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L83" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="83"></td>
          <td id="LC83" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   a population, collecting baseline characteristics $W$, randomly assigning </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L84" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="84"></td>
          <td id="LC84" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   treatment $A$, and then later measuring an outcome $Y$. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L85" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="85"></td>
          <td id="LC85" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">2.</span> <span class="pl-mb">**A statistical model $<span class="pl-cce">\M</span>$ as a set of possible probability distributions**</span> </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L86" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="86"></td>
          <td id="LC86" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   <span class="pl-mb">**that could have given rise to the data.**</span> It&#39;s essential for $<span class="pl-cce">\M</span>$ to only </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L87" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="87"></td>
          <td id="LC87" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   constrained by factual subject-matter knowledge in order to guarantee $P_0$ </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L88" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="88"></td>
          <td id="LC88" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   resides in the statistical model, written $P_0 <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n <span class="pl-cce">\M</span>$. Continuing </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L89" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="89"></td>
          <td id="LC89" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   the example from step 1, the following restrictions could be placed on the </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L90" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="90"></td>
          <td id="LC90" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   statistical model: the $O_1, <span class="pl-cce">\l</span>dots, O_n$ observations in the data are </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L91" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="91"></td>
          <td id="LC91" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), the assignment of </td>

          <td id="L1074" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1074"></td>
          <td id="LC1074" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1075" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1075"></td>
          <td id="LC1075" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We can cross-validate the SL to see how well the SL performs on unseen data, and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1076" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1076"></td>
          <td id="LC1076" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">obtain an estimate of the cross-validated risk of the SL.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1077" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1077"></td>
          <td id="LC1077" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1078" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1078"></td>
          <td id="LC1078" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This estimation procedure requires an outer/external layer of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1079" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1079"></td>
          <td id="LC1079" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cross-validation, also called nested cross-validation, which involves setting</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1080" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1080"></td>
          <td id="LC1080" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">aside a separate holdout sample that we dont use to fit the SL. This external</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1081" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1081"></td>
          <td id="LC1081" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cross-validation procedure may also incorporate 10 folds, which is the default</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1082" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1082"></td>
          <td id="LC1082" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span>. However, we will incorporate 2 outer/external folds of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1083" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1083"></td>
          <td id="LC1083" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cross-validation for computational efficiency.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1084" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1084"></td>
          <td id="LC1084" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1085" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1085"></td>
          <td id="LC1085" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We also need to specify a loss function to evaluate SL. Documentation for the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1086" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1086"></td>
          <td id="LC1086" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">available loss functions can be found in the [<span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> Loss Function</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1087" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1087"></td>
          <td id="LC1087" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Reference](https://tlverse.org/sl3/reference/loss_functions.html).</td>
        </tr>

          <td id="LC1088" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>

        </tr>

        </tr>

        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1103" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1103"></td>
          <td id="LC1103" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1104" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1104"></td>
          <td id="LC1104" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">&lt;!--</span> Explain summary!!!! <span class="pl-c">--&gt;</span></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1105" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1105"></td>
          <td id="LC1105" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1106" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1106"></td>
          <td id="LC1106" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Variable Importance Measures with <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> {-}</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1107" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1107"></td>
          <td id="LC1107" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1108" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1108"></td>
          <td id="LC1108" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Variable importance can be interesting and informative. It can also be</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1109" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1109"></td>
          <td id="LC1109" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">contradictory and confusing. Nevertheless, we like it, and so do our</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1110" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1110"></td>
          <td id="LC1110" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">collaborators, so we created a variable importance function in <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span>! The <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1111" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1111"></td>
          <td id="LC1111" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">`importance`</span> function returns a table with variables listed in decreasing order</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1112" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1112"></td>
          <td id="LC1112" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of importance (i.e., most important on the first row).</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1113" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1113"></td>
          <td id="LC1113" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1114" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1114"></td>
          <td id="LC1114" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The measure of importance in <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> is based on a risk ratio, or risk difference,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1115" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1115"></td>
          <td id="LC1115" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">between the learner fit with a removed, or permuted, covariate and the learner</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1116" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1116"></td>
          <td id="LC1116" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fit with the true covariate, across all covariates. In this manner, the larger</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1117" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1117"></td>
          <td id="LC1117" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the risk difference, the more important the variable is in the prediction.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1118" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1118"></td>
          <td id="LC1118" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1119" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1119"></td>
          <td id="LC1119" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The intuition of this measure is that it calculates the risk (in terms of the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1120" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1120"></td>
          <td id="LC1120" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">average loss in predictive accuracy) of losing one covariate, while keeping</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1121" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1121"></td>
          <td id="LC1121" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">everything else fixed, and compares it to the risk if the covariate was not</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1122" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1122"></td>
          <td id="LC1122" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">lost. If this risk ratio is one, or risk difference is zero, then losing that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1123" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1123"></td>
          <td id="LC1123" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariate had no impact, and is thus not important by this measure. We do this</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1124" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1124"></td>
          <td id="LC1124" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">across all of the covariates. As stated above, we can remove the covariate and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1125" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1125"></td>
          <td id="LC1125" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">refit the SL without it, or we just permute the covariate (faster)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1126" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1126"></td>
          <td id="LC1126" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and hope for the shuffling to distort any meaningful information that was</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1127" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1127"></td>
          <td id="LC1127" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">present in the covariate. This idea of permuting instead of removing saves a lot</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1128" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1128"></td>
          <td id="LC1128" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of time, and is also incorporated in the <span class="pl-c1">`randomForest`</span> variable importance</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1129" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1129"></td>
          <td id="LC1129" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">measures. However, the permutation approach is risky, so the importance function</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1130" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1130"></td>
          <td id="LC1130" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">default is to remove and refit.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1131" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1131"></td>
          <td id="LC1131" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1132" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1132"></td>
          <td id="LC1132" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Let&#39;s explore the <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> variable importance measurements for the <span class="pl-c1">`washb`</span> data.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1133" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1133"></td>
          <td id="LC1133" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1134" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1134"></td>
          <td id="LC1134" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r varimp}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1135" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1135"></td>
          <td id="LC1135" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">washb_varimp</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> importance(<span class="pl-smi">sl_fit</span>, <span class="pl-v">loss</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">loss_squared_error</span>, <span class="pl-v">type</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>permute<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>)</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1136" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1136"></td>
          <td id="LC1136" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">washb_varimp</span> %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC1137" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  kable(<span class="pl-v">digits</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">4</span>) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1138" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1138"></td>
          <td id="LC1138" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  <span class="pl-e">kableExtra</span><span class="pl-k">:::</span>kable_styling(<span class="pl-v">fixed_thead</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>) %<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>%</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1139" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1139"></td>
          <td id="LC1139" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">  scroll_box(<span class="pl-v">width</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>100%<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">height</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>300px<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>)</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC1186" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">2.</span> Make a library of seven relatively fast base learning algorithms (i.e., do</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1187" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1187"></td>

        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1188" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1188"></td>
          <td id="LC1188" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   learners. Feel free to use learners from <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> or <span class="pl-c1">`SuperLearner`</span>. You may</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1189" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1189"></td>
          <td id="LC1189" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   use the same base learning library that is presented above.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1190" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1190"></td>
          <td id="LC1190" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">3.</span> Incorporate at least one pipeline with feature selection. Any screener and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1191" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1191"></td>

        </tr>

          <td id="L1195" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1195"></td>
          <td id="LC1195" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">6.</span> Print the SL fit results by adding <span class="pl-c1">`$cv_risk(loss_squared_error)`</span> to your </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1196" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1196"></td>
          <td id="LC1196" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   fit object. The squared error loss is specified here, since that&#39;s what is </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1197" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1197"></td>
          <td id="LC1197" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   used by the default metalearner.</td>
        </tr>

          <td id="L1198" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1198"></td>

          <td id="L1199" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1199"></td>
          <td id="LC1199" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   Specify the <span class="pl-c1">`loss_squared_error`</span> loss function to evaluate the SL as it&#39;s </td>

        <tr>

</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1205" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1205"></td>
          <td id="LC1205" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">&lt;!--</span></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1206" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1206"></td>
          <td id="LC1206" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">## Super Learning of a Conditional Density</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1207" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1207"></td>
          <td id="LC1207" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1208" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1208"></td>
          <td id="LC1208" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">### Super learning of a conditional density</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1209" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1209"></td>
          <td id="LC1209" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1210" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1210"></td>
          <td id="LC1210" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">Suppose we want to construct a Super Learner of the conditional probability</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1211" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1211"></td>
          <td id="LC1211" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">distribution $g_0(a\mid W)=P_0(A=a\mid W)$, where $a\in {\cal A}$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1212" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1212"></td>
          <td id="LC1212" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">Let&#39;s denote the values of $a$ with $\{0,1,\ldots,K\}$. A valid loss function</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1213" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1213"></td>
          <td id="LC1213" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">for the conditional density is</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1214" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1214"></td>
          <td id="LC1214" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">\[</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1215" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1215"></td>
          <td id="LC1215" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">L(g)(O)=-\log g(A\mid W).\]</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1216" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1216"></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1297" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1297"></td>
          <td id="LC1297" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">address issues related to this</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1298" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1298"></td>
          <td id="LC1298" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1299" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1299"></td>
          <td id="LC1299" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">## Super Learning of an Optimal Individualized Treatment Rule</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1300" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1300"></td>
          <td id="LC1300" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1301" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1301"></td>
          <td id="LC1301" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Data $O=(W,A,Y)$, and nonparametric model \M potentially containing</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1302" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1302"></td>
          <td id="LC1302" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">assumptions on the conditional probability distribution of $A$ given $W$</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1303" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1303"></td>
          <td id="LC1303" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">$g_0(A\mid W)$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1304" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1304"></td>
          <td id="LC1304" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Target: Optimal treatment rule $\psi_0(W)=I(B_0(W)&gt;0)$, where</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1305" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1305"></td>
          <td id="LC1305" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">$B_0(W)=E_0(Y\mid A=1,W)-E_0(Y\mid A=0,W)$, the conditional treatment effect.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1306" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1306"></td>
          <td id="LC1306" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Possible loss function for $\psi_0$ is an IPCW-loss:</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1307" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1307"></td>
          <td id="LC1307" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">\[</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1308" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1308"></td>
          <td id="LC1308" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">L_{g_0}(\psi)=\frac{I(A=\psi(W))}{g(A\mid W)}Y.\]</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1309" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1309"></td>
          <td id="LC1309" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1310" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1310"></td>
          <td id="LC1310" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">Indeed, $\psi_0$ is the minimizer of $EL_{g_0}(\psi)$ over all rules $\psi$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1311" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1311"></td>
          <td id="LC1311" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Construct library of candidate estimators of $\psi_0=I(B_0&gt;0)$. This can</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1312" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1312"></td>
          <td id="LC1312" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">include estimators based on plugging in an estimator of $B_0$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1313" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1313"></td>
          <td id="LC1313" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* One could also include a candidate estimator $I(B_n&gt;0)$ where $B_n$ is a</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1314" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1314"></td>
          <td id="LC1314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">Super Learner of $B_0$, e.g. based on loss function</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1315" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1315"></td>
          <td id="LC1315" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">\[</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1316" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1316"></td>
          <td id="LC1316" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">L_{g_0}(B)=\big(\frac{2A-1}{/g(A\mid W)}Y-B(W)\big)^2\]</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1317" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1317"></td>
          <td id="LC1317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">that directly targets $B_0=\arg\min_B P_0L_{g_0}(B)$. This loss function is</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1318" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1318"></td>
          <td id="LC1318" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">still a squared error loss but its minimized by the true $B_0$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1319" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1319"></td>
          <td id="LC1319" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Estimate $g_0$ if not known.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1320" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1320"></td>
          <td id="LC1320" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Compute cross-validation selector:</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1321" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1321"></td>
          <td id="LC1321" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">\[</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1322" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1322"></td>
          <td id="LC1322" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">k_n=\arg\min_k E_{B_n}P_{n,B_n}^1 L_{\hat{g}(P_{n,B_n}^0)}</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1323" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1323"></td>
          <td id="LC1323" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">(\hat{\Psi}_k(P_{n,B_n}^0)).\]</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1324" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1324"></td>
          <td id="LC1324" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">where $B_n = \{0,1\}^n$ is used for a binary vector of $n$ defining sample</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1325" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1325"></td>
          <td id="LC1325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">splits, where the validation sample is ${i:B_n(i) = 1}$ and ${i:B_n(i) = 0}$ is</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1326" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1326"></td>
          <td id="LC1326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">the training sample. The empirical distribution $P_{n,B_n}^0$ corresponds to</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1327" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1327"></td>
          <td id="LC1327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">the split $B_n$ of the training sample and the empirical distribution of the</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1328" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1328"></td>
          <td id="LC1328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">validation sample is $P_{n,B_n}^1$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1329" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1329"></td>
          <td id="LC1329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">* Super-learner of optimal rule $\psi_0$: $\hat{\Psi}_{k_n}(P_n)$.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1330" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1330"></td>
          <td id="LC1330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1331" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1331"></td>
          <td id="LC1331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">## Exercise 3 -- Estimating the Blip {#sl3ex3}</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1332" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1332"></td>
          <td id="LC1332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1333" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1333"></td>
          <td id="LC1333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">--&gt;</span></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1334" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1334"></td>
          <td id="LC1334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1335" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1335"></td>
          <td id="LC1335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Concluding Remarks</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1336" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1336"></td>
          <td id="LC1336" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1337" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1337"></td>
          <td id="LC1337" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> Super Learner (SL) is a general approach that can be applied to a diversity of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1338" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1338"></td>
          <td id="LC1338" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  estimation and prediction problems which can be defined by a loss function.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1339" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1339"></td>
          <td id="LC1339" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1340" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1340"></td>
          <td id="LC1340" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> It would be straightforward to plug in the estimator returned by SL into the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1341" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1341"></td>
          <td id="LC1341" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  target parameter mapping.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1342" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1342"></td>
          <td id="LC1342" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    <span class="pl-v">+</span> For example, suppose we are after the average treatment effect (ATE) of a</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1343" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1343"></td>
          <td id="LC1343" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      binary treatment intervention:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1344" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1344"></td>
          <td id="LC1344" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      $<span class="pl-cce">\P</span>si_0 = E_{0,W}[E_0(Y|A=1,W) - E_0(Y|A=0,W)]$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1345" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1345"></td>
          <td id="LC1345" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    <span class="pl-v">+</span> We could use the SL that was trained on the original data (let&#39;s call</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1346" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1346"></td>
          <td id="LC1346" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      this <span class="pl-c1">`sl_fit`</span>) to predict the outcome for all subjects under each</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1347" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1347"></td>
          <td id="LC1347" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      intervention. All we would need to do is take the average difference</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1348" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1348"></td>
          <td id="LC1348" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      between the counterfactual outcomes under each intervention of interest.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1349" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1349"></td>
          <td id="LC1349" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    <span class="pl-v">+</span> Considering $<span class="pl-cce">\P</span>si_0$ above, we would first need two $n$-length vectors of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1350" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1350"></td>
          <td id="LC1350" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      predicted outcomes under each intervention. One vector would represent</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1351" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1351"></td>
          <td id="LC1351" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      the predicted outcomes under an intervention that sets all subjects to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1352" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1352"></td>
          <td id="LC1352" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      receive $A=1$, $Y_i|A_i=1,W_i$ for all $i=1,<span class="pl-cce">\l</span>dots,n$. The other vector</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1353" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1353"></td>
          <td id="LC1353" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      would represent the predicted outcomes under an intervention that sets</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1354" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1354"></td>
          <td id="LC1354" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      all subjects to receive $A=0$, $Y_i|A_i=0,W_i$ for all $i=1,<span class="pl-cce">\l</span>dots,n$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1355" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1355"></td>
          <td id="LC1355" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    <span class="pl-v">+</span> After obtaining these vectors of counterfactual predicted outcomes, all</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1356" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1356"></td>
          <td id="LC1356" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      we would need to do is average and then take the difference in order to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1357" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1357"></td>
          <td id="LC1357" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      &quot;plug-in&quot; the SL estimator into the target parameter mapping.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1358" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1358"></td>
          <td id="LC1358" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    <span class="pl-v">+</span> In <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> and with our current ATE example, this could be achieved with</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1359" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1359"></td>
          <td id="LC1359" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      <span class="pl-c1">`mean(sl_fit$predict(A1_task)) - mean(sl_fit$predict(A0_task))`</span>;</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1360" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1360"></td>
          <td id="LC1360" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      where <span class="pl-c1">`A1_task$data`</span> would contain all 1&#39;s (or the level that pertains to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1361" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1361"></td>
          <td id="LC1361" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      receiving the treatment) for the treatment column in the data (keeping</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1362" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1362"></td>
          <td id="LC1362" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      all else the same), and <span class="pl-c1">`A0_task$data`</span> would contain all 0&#39;s (or the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1363" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1363"></td>
          <td id="LC1363" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      level that pertains to not receiving the treatment) for the treatment</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1364" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1364"></td>
          <td id="LC1364" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">      column in the data.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1365" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1365"></td>
          <td id="LC1365" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">-</span> It&#39;s a worthwhile exercise to obtain the predicted counterfactual outcomes</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1366" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1366"></td>
          <td id="LC1366" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  and create these counterfactual <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> tasks. It&#39;s too biased; however, to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1367" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1367"></td>
          <td id="LC1367" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  plug the SL fit into the target parameter mapping, (e.g., calling the result</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1368" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1368"></td>
          <td id="LC1368" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  of <span class="pl-c1">`mean(sl_fit$predict(A1_task)) - mean(sl_fit$predict(A0_task))`</span> the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1369" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1369"></td>

          <td id="LC1373" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  estimating $<span class="pl-cce">\p</span>si_0$. The SL is an essential step to help us get there. In</td>

</td>

          <td id="LC1387" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  <span class="pl-v">+</span> An efficient estimator is optimal in the sense that it has the lowest</td>

</td>

          <td id="LC1394" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">        difficulty of the estimation problem [ADD REF]. Various canonical </td>

</td>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC1402" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  asymptotically linear plug-in estimators.</td>

        <tr>

</td>

          <td id="L1410" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1410"></td>
          <td id="LC1410" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">&lt;!--</span></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1411" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1411"></td>
          <td id="LC1411" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">We could just plug-in the estimator returned by Super Learner; however, this is</span></td>

          <td id="LC1414" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">of convergence of these algorithms, which is always slower than $1/\sqrt{n}$.</span></td>

          <td id="LC1417" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">bias as what we plugged in, which is greater than $1/\sqrt{n}$. Thus, we end up</span></td>

          <td id="L1418" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1418"></td>
          <td id="LC1418" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">with an estimator which is not asymptotically normal, since it does not</span></td>

          <td id="LC1419" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">converge to the estimand at $1/\sqrt{n}$ rate.</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1420" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1420"></td>
          <td id="LC1420" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1421" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1421"></td>
          <td id="LC1421" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">An asymptotically linear estimator has no meaningful bias ($ &lt; 1/\sqrt{n}$),</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1422" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1422"></td>
          <td id="LC1422" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">and can be written as an empirical mean in first order of a function of the</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC1423" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">data, the influence curve, plus some negligible remainder term. Once an</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1424" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1424"></td>
          <td id="LC1424" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">estimator is asymptotically linear with an influence curve its normally</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1425" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1425"></td>
          <td id="LC1425" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">distributed, so the standardized estimator converges to a normal distribution</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1426" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1426"></td>
          <td id="LC1426" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">with mean 0 and variance is the variance of the influence curve. Thus, it is</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1427" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1427"></td>
          <td id="LC1427" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">advantageous to construct asymptotically linear estimators since they permit</span></td>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC1430" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">thats the one with influence curve equal to the canonical gradient of the</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1431" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1431"></td>
          <td id="LC1431" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">path-wise derivative of the target parameter. The canonical gradient is the</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1432" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1432"></td>
          <td id="LC1432" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">direction of the path through the data distribution where the parameter is</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1433" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1433"></td>
          <td id="LC1433" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">steepest. An estimator is efficient if and only if is asymptotically linear</span></td>
        </tr>

          <td id="L1434" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1434"></td>
          <td id="LC1434" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">with influence curve equal to the canonical gradient. One can calculate the</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1435" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1435"></td>
          <td id="LC1435" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">canonical gradient with the statistical model and the statistical target</span></td>

          <td id="LC1436" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">parameter.  Techniques for calculating the canonical gradient entail projecting</span></td>

        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1438" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1438"></td>
          <td id="LC1438" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">distribution in the model in which you want to calculate the canonical</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1439" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1439"></td>
          <td id="LC1439" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">gradient.</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1440" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1440"></td>
          <td id="LC1440" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1441" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1441"></td>
          <td id="LC1441" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">Now we know what it takes to construct an efficient estimator. Namely, we need</span></td>

          <td id="LC1443" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">the canonical gradient. There are three general classes of estimators which</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC1444" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">succeed in constructing asymptotically linear estimators: (1) the one-step</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1445" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1445"></td>
          <td id="LC1445" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">estimator, but it is not a plug-in estimator; (2) the targeted maximum</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1446" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1446"></td>
          <td id="LC1446" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">likelihood estimator, which is a Super Learner targeted towards the target</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1447" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1447"></td>
          <td id="LC1447" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">parameter and it is a plug-in estimator; and (3) estimating equation based</span></td>
